thread.title: Arsene Wenger's position is now untenable after Arsenal suffer another sorry European capitulation
thread.title_full: Arsene Wenger's position is now untenable after Arsenal suffer another sorry European capitulation

author: John Cross
title: Arsene Wenger's position is now untenable after Arsenal suffer another sorry European capitulation
text:
Sport Opinion Arsene Wenger's position is now untenable after Arsenal suffer another sorry European capitulation Arsenal supporters staged a small protest outside of the Emirates ahead of the second 5-1 hammering against Bayern Share It proved to be another night to forget for Wenger (Photo: Shaun Botterill) Share Get Arsenal FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The night actually started well before turning into complete and utter humiliation. 
But as the goals rained in during another second half meltdown, the pressure on Arsene Wenger mounted to the point of his position surely becoming untenable. 
In fairness, the boos from the Arsenal fans at the final whistle were more aimed at Greek referee Tasos Sidiropoulos and his fellow officials. 
Laurent Koscielny’s controversial red card at the start of the second half was the signal for the floodgates to open and Bayern Munich took Arsenal apart. 
But there was still no excuse for another sorry, miserable capitulation which was exactly the same story and scoreline from the first leg in the Allianz Arena. Koscielny's red card proved to be the turning point (Photo: Getty) Arsenal found themselves beaten 5-1 once again (Photo: REUTERS) 
Bayern are a brilliant side but you cannot take Arsenal seriously as a genuine European force if you concede TEN goals over the course of two legs. 
The first half gave Arsenal hope, Theo Walcott fired them into a half time lead and restored some pride with a battling, brave response to restore some pride. 
But the second half, ten men or not, highlighted all of Arsenal’s problems as Bayern cut through the home defence like a knife through butter. Theo Walcott gave Arsenal some early optimism (Photo: Shaun Botterill) But it all turned sour quickly for Arsenal (Photo: Shaun Botterill) 
The defending became non-existent, they waved Bayern through for wave after wave of attacks and Arsenal merely collapsed. 
Just as with the first leg when Koscielny went off injured, as soon as Arsenal’s captain was off the pitch they lost all their organisation and, most worryingly of all, they had no leaders. 
Well, unless you count Petr Cech, Arsenal’s only Champions League winner, but he was on the bench because Wenger starts European games with David Ospina. 
There should be no room for such sentiment or charity in football. Wenger has relied on sentiment for too long, living off the back of his previous achievements in his glorious first ten years at the club. The protests outside of the Emirates were only small before the game (Photo: REUTERS) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
